slides.title: Introduction to the Science of Environment
content: The science of environment thoroughly studies physics, chemistry, and biology of environment.
Understanding interactions between air, water, and land is vital for environmental scientists.
This knowledge helps in addressing pollution and effectively managing environmental resources.
Engineers need the basics to address challenges in environmental science and technology.
slides.script: Welcome to Chapter 2, where we delve into the core sciences underpinning environmental understanding.  This slide emphasizes the importance of a strong foundation in physics, chemistry, and biology. We will discuss why they are essential to understanding the complex interactions within our environment and will guide us toward effective solutions for environmental issues and challenges.

slides.title: Water Quality Parameters: Physical Properties
content: Physical water quality parameters respond to sight, touch, taste or smell, and they are easy to notice.
Suspended solids can spoil water's appearance and cause objectionable by-products and reduce potability.
Turbidity is caused by suspended particles and affects aesthetics and filtration and disinfections.
Color in water is caused by dissolved and suspended matter affecting the suitability of the water.
Taste and odor are also related to organic and inorganic substances in water supplies.
Temperature affects biological activity, chemical reaction rates, and gas solubility in water.
slides.script: This slide highlights the physical parameters that affect water quality.  Suspended solids, turbidity, color, taste, odor, and temperature are crucial indicators of water's suitability for various uses. We will cover why these parameters are important and how they are impacted by several factors such as domestic, agriculture, and industrial use.

slides.title: Chemical Water Quality Parameters
content: Chemical parameters include pH, hardness, dissolved solids, metals, organics, surfactants, nutrients.
pH indicates acidity or alkalinity and is crucial for drinking water suitability and several reactions.
Hardness is caused by dissolved metallic cations and forms precipitates with soap and causes scaling.
Total Dissolved Solids (TDS) measures the dissolved material impacting aesthetics, taste, and safety.
slides.script: Now, let's look at chemical water quality parameters. These include pH, hardness, dissolved solids, metals, organics, surfactants, and nutrients. Each of these parameters is important and will be covered in detail to give you an overall comprehensive understanding.

slides.title: Chemical Parameters: Metals, Organics, Nutrients
content: Excessive amounts of metals in water can pose health hazards and should be measured accurately.
Organic materials in water result in color, taste, and odor and can be divided into biodegradable and non.
Nutrients, especially nitrogen and phosphorus, affect plant life and oxygen levels in aquatic ecosystems.
Nitrogen and phosphorus sources are atmospheric processes and runoff from agricultural land.
Over enrichment of nitrogen and phosphorus leads to adverse environmental issues.
Phosphates interfere with the water treatment processes which require specific management techniques.
slides.script: Continuing with chemical parameters, we focus on metals, organics, and nutrients.  We will cover the roles, sources, impacts, and measurement techniques of each of these key groups of substances to evaluate water quality.

slides.title: Biological Water Quality Parameters
content: Biological parameters include pathogens like bacteria, viruses, protozoa, and helminths.
Waterborne pathogens can transmit diseases making their detection and disinfection extremely crucial.
Indicator organism techniques, like testing for coliform bacteria, is used for checking pathogens presence.
Effective treatment is necessary for pathogens to avoid human health issues and diseases.
slides.script: Next up are the biological water quality parameters.  We will be focusing on pathogens and how it is crucial to test and disinfect for them. Different organisms require different management techniques.

slides.title: Atmospheric Components: Ions and Radicals
content: Ions in the atmosphere include O+, NO+ exist in the ionosphere and are generated by solar UV radiations.
Free radicals generated by photochemical reactions are highly reactive and can be organic or inorganic.
These radicals interact with other chemical components producing a series of chain reactions that impact air quality.
slides.script: This slide introduces the ionic and radical components of the atmosphere.  These chemically active species play important roles in atmospheric processes, influencing air quality and climate.

slides.title: Atmospheric Components: Particulate Matter
content: Particulate matter comprises particles of sizes ranging from 0.1 µm to 10 µm.
Aerosols are particles with colloidal dimensions contributing to particulate matter.
Dust, fog, ash, mist, smoke, pollen, fumes, and bacteria contribute to the presence of particulate matter.
Particulate matter is generated by natural and anthropogenic means (Volcanic eruptions vs Industrial exhaust).
It is a health hazard and also leads to certain beneficial effects that create conditions for cloud formation.
slides.script: Now, we move on to particulate matter. These particles are both organic and inorganic and come from a variety of sources and will be covered in detail.

slides.title: Chemical and Photochemical Reactions
content: Oxides of nitrogen (NOx) originate from burning fossil fuels that decompose to NO that depletes ozone.
Oxidation of NO2 and absorption in water produces nitric acid causing acid rain that severely impacts soil pH.
Oxides of Sulphur (SOx) also originate from burning fossil fuels.
They are oxidized to SO3 in the presence of moisture converts to H2SO4 contributing to acid rain.
slides.script: This slide explains the chemical and photochemical reactions happening in the atmosphere.  These processes involve key pollutants such as nitrogen and sulfur oxides and influence ozone depletion and acid rain formation.

slides.title: Formation of Photochemical Smog
content: Alkyl/aryl radicals react with oxygen forming peroxyl radicals that react with NO2 generating PAN and aldehydes.
Photochemical smog result in disruption/accidents in air and road traffic because of its poor visibility.
Ozone, Peroxyacyl nitrate (PAN), carbon monoxide, ketones and aldehydes contribute to photochemical smogs.
It causes irritation to the eyes and lungs and leads to chronic respiratory problems and polymer degradation.
slides.script: Here, we describe the formation and consequences of photochemical smog, resulting from reactions involving nitrogen oxides, hydrocarbons, and solar radiation. We will cover the dangers of this pollutant.

slides.title: Ozone Layer Chemistry and Impacts
content: Ozone (O3) in the stratosphere absorbs incoming UV radiation from the sun, protecting life.
It is continuously formed in the stratosphere by photochemical reactions and is also destroyed.
Reactions with chlorine from CFCs cause ozone depletion affecting the future.
Stratospheric ozone depletion causes UV radiation related health problems, and issues on the marine chain.
Reducing the use of Chlorofluorocarbons (CFC) can avoid damages.
slides.script: Ozone chemistry and depletion is the main focus here, as it covers the significance of the ozone layer in protecting us from UV radiation. We will also discuss the processes responsible for ozone depletion, including reactions with CFCs.

slides.title: Atmospheric Bioaerosols
content: Bioaerosols are microorganisms dispersed in the air such as dust mites, molds, fungi and fragments of living things.
They cannot be seen without a magnifying glass or microscope which makes them hard to detect.
Many of the bioaerosols are Viruses and bacteria, cause infections (like a cold or pneumonia). Others cause allergies.
Reduction in humidity, ensuring adequate ventilation and keeping regular cleaning to reduce the risk of exposure.
slides.script: Now we will talk about bioaerosols in the atmosphere and what their effects are on human health.  Minimizing generation is the best way to tackle this. We will cover what these methods are.

slides.title: Chemical Composition of Soil
content: Earth's crust consists of rocks and loose derivatives of these rocks like gravel, sand, silt and clay.
The crust is made up of major elements like oxygen, silicon, aluminium and iron.
Rocks are classified into igneous, sedimentary and metamorphic rocks.
Soils are formed by the interaction of the rocks with wind, rain and heat, forming sand, silt, gravel and clays.
Weathering process can be physical, chemical and biological resulting in different compositions.
slides.script: Moving to the soil, we examine the elemental composition, rock types, and the weathering processes that contribute to soil formation.  We will cover how these factors all affect soil composition and influence ecosystems.

slides.title: Soil Components and Functions
content: Soil contains mineral matter (sand, silt, and clay), organic matter (humus), soil moisture and air.
The organic matter contains decayed products of plants and animals contributing to the nutritional value.
The soil also houses wide range of organisms like bacteria, algae, fungi which are termed as Edaphons.
Provides a platform for growth of plants that help in regeneration, and fixing of nutrients and helps in mineralization.
slides.script: Focusing on the components of soil, we discuss the roles of mineral and organic matter, moisture, and air in supporting plant life and nutrient cycles. Humification and biological activity of organisms influence these processes.

slides.title: Soil Pollution and Utilization
content: Indiscriminate dumping of industrial, municipal and biomedical wastes leads to soil pollution.
Intensive agricultural practices contaminate soil and water with fertilizers and pesticides.
Disruption of hydrological cycle, pollution of water, loss of biodiversity are some of the impacts of this.
Development of policies and correct solid waste disposal techniques can mitigate the soil pollution.
Waste minimization and recycling will also reduce the effect.s.
slides.script: Here we discuss waste utilization and soil pollution, and how the pollution is caused. Proper land and waste management is essential. We will cover all details of such measures.

slides.title: Environmental Pollution: Sources and Impacts
content: Environmental stress may be defined as a condition of intense strain or pressure.
Higher population, urbanization and industrialization lead to increase demand on resources.
Increase in hazardous nature and complex number of the wastes poses an acute stress.
Thermal, Radiation, Noise and chemical agents cause severe physical stress to both environment and humans.
Biological factors are a result of organic emissions. and are commonly referred to as pathogenic organisms.
There may be many impacts associated with the issues above requiring a focus global effort.
slides.script: Finally, we summarize the sources and impacts of environmental stresses and identify their relationship to thermal and chemical pollutants. Understanding these processes can improve the planet and human health.
